awd_titl_txt: Designer Silver Catalysts for Selective Bond Amidations
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Jennifer Schomaker of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Wisconsin Madison to design new catalysts that convert feedstock chemicals into useful building blocks for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals. The silver catalysts that are being developed change common parts of organic molecules called alkenes and alkanes into nitrogen-containing groups called amines. Importantly, these catalysts are also being tuned to select a specific type of alkene or alkane to undergo the amination process within a molecule containing multiple examples of alkane and/or alkene bonds.  Professor Schomaker and her diverse team of graduate and undergraduate researchers are examining questions about how these catalysts work in order to learn how to improve their performance for the advanced manufacturing of chemicals and materials. Portions of this study are also being adapted for undergraduate teaching laboratory experiments to engage students at an early stage in research experiences.  Green aspects of this project are being pursued in teaching laboratory course activities that provide guided inquiry opportunities for undergraduates.

The development of low-cost, modular catalysts for the tunable conversion of C-H bonds to C-N bonds is a long-standing challenge that is crucial for achieving streamlined syntheses of important molecular fragments in pharmaceutical and material applications. To address this issue, Professor Schomaker and her research group are designing silver catalysts that can control the selective transformation of C-H bonds to C-N bonds through metal-catalyzed nitrene transfer processes. These investigations combine mechanistic, spectroscopic, and computational studies to understand how the different structural elements of the silver catalysts influence interactions with substrates and promote selective reactivity with specific C-H bonds. Case studies are also being explored to illustrate the impact of these new synthetic tools for the preparation of enantioenriched amines, the construction of synthetic building blocks for pharmaceuticals, and the design of novel amino sugars. Ultimately, this work is establishing general design principles for new silver catalysts that can override innate reactivity preferences and do not require a directing group for C-H amidation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Designer Silver Catalysts for Selective Bond Amidations.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Transition metal-catalyzed C–H amidation via nitrene transfer (NT) offers the tantalizing potential to form valuable C–N bonds with excellent atom economy from simple hydrocarbon feedstocks to streamline the syntheses of value-added amine building blocks. Despite progress in the field by many top-notch research groups, significant challenges need to be addressed to improve the versatility, utility and sustainability of NT to harness its full potential. A good catalyst must be both reactive enough to break strong C–H bonds but also selective enough to target only the desired C–H bond. With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Jennifer Schomaker of the University of Wisconsin is developing low-cost, modular catalysts for the tunable functionalization of C–H bonds to valuable C–N bonds. NSF funding has been key to continuing to build and leverage our knowledge of tunable silver catalysis to expand the efficiency and selectivity of chemo-, regio- and enantiocontrolled NT reactions of C=C and C–H bonds. Over the course of this award, our group has designed low-cost, modular catalysts to transform diverse C–H bonds into valuable carbon-nitrogen (C–N) bonds. Noteworthy accomplishments pertaining to both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of this program include:

  • Intellectual merits of combining experiment, mechanistic understanding, spectroscopy and computations of silver(I) coordination complexes and their behavior in NT chemistry led to the development of a new class of chiral ligands for asymmetric NT of benzylic, allylic, propargylic and unactivated methylene C–H bonds. These new catalysts can have broad impacts in furnishing enantioenriched amine building blocks for agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals.
  • Insights into catalyst behavior enabled us to harness non-covalent interactions in the transition state and favor amination of e-poor C–H bonds over more e-rich ones to reverse the normal pattern of reactivity. Given the prevalence of heterocycles in drug molecules, there will be broad interest in these new tools for installing amine functionality adjacent to pyridines, pyrimidines and other e-poor heterocycles.
  • Site-selective, silver-catalyzed NT of sulfamates led to the serendipitous discovery of a new class of molecules that inhibit KasA, an underexplored Mtb target involved in cell wall biosynthesis. This has spun off NIH R21 funding to study structure-activity relationships and use our silver chemistry to develop analogs with improved activity and ADMET properties.
  • Intellectual contributions from several lab members stimulated new combinations of nitrene precursors and silver catalysts for chemoselective aza-Büchner reactions to arenes to access versatile azepine scaffolds. Future work will elaborate these unusual building blocks to explore novel azepane chemical space that is underrepresented in current drug screening libraries.
  • The development and implementation of a high-throughput experimentation platform for the heterogenous silver-catalyzed NT reactions uncovered several unexpected and more environmentally friendly solvents to replace the usual chlorinated solvents used for NT. These discoveries will facilitate more ready adoption of our methods by industrial collaborators.

   In addition to broad impacts associated with streamlining industrially important reactions and minimizing environmental impact, this project has provided several post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students with numerous opportunities for technical training and professional development. For example, our collaboration with Prof. Peng Liu has enabled group members to travel to Pitt to learn ab initio computational methods. Students on the project have presented their work at conferences that include ACS meetings, the National Organic Symposium and several Gordon Research Conferences. Eleven Ph.D. students have received training under this NSF grant, five of whom are women and two of whom are underrepresented students in STEM. Graduate students have had opportunities to hone their experimental techniques, learn advanced spectroscopic techniques, meld experimental work with computation and data science, participate in outreach and educational activities, and take on leadership roles in conceptualizing and mentoring younger students in new project areas. These activities have been key to increasing their big-picture view of the project, exercising their creativity and developing their organizational/leadership skills, preparing them for leadership positions in academia, the chemical industry or government. In addition, three undergraduates have played key roles in this work and are listed as co-authors on publications funded by this grant. Students supported by this work have gone on to industry positions at GSK, BMS, PPD and other pharmaceutical companies, national labs (Los Alamos National Lab), academic positions at University of South Florida and Ohio University and Ph.D. programs at the University of Florida and Princeton.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2024
Modified by: Jennifer M Schomaker
por.por_txt_cntn:
Designer Silver Catalysts for Selective Bond Amidations.


PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT


Transition metal-catalyzed CH amidation via nitrene transfer (NT) offers the tantalizing potential to form valuable CN bonds with excellent atom economy from simple hydrocarbon feedstocks to streamline the syntheses of value-added amine building blocks. Despite progress in the field by many top-notch research groups, significant challenges need to be addressed to improve the versatility, utility and sustainability of NT to harness its full potential. A good catalyst must be both reactive enough to break strong CH bonds but also selective enough to target only the desired CH bond. With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Jennifer Schomaker of the University of Wisconsin is developing low-cost, modular catalysts for the tunable functionalization of CH bonds to valuable CN bonds. NSF funding has been key to continuing to build and leverage our knowledge of tunable silver catalysis to expand the efficiency and selectivity of chemo-, regio- and enantiocontrolled NT reactions of C=C and CH bonds. Over the course of this award, our group has designed low-cost, modular catalysts to transform diverse CH bonds into valuable carbon-nitrogen (CN) bonds. Noteworthy accomplishments pertaining to both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of this program include:

Intellectual merits of combining experiment, mechanistic understanding, spectroscopy and computations of silver(I) coordination complexes and their behavior in NT chemistry led to the development of a new class of chiral ligands for asymmetric NT of benzylic, allylic, propargylic and unactivated methylene CH bonds. These new catalysts can have broad impacts in furnishing enantioenriched amine building blocks for agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals.
Insights into catalyst behavior enabled us to harness non-covalent interactions in the transition state and favor amination of e-poor CH bonds over more e-rich ones to reverse the normal pattern of reactivity. Given the prevalence of heterocycles in drug molecules, there will be broad interest in these new tools for installing amine functionality adjacent to pyridines, pyrimidines and other e-poor heterocycles.
Site-selective, silver-catalyzed NT of sulfamates led to the serendipitous discovery of a new class of molecules that inhibit KasA, an underexplored Mtb target involved in cell wall biosynthesis. This has spun off NIH R21 funding to study structure-activity relationships and use our silver chemistry to develop analogs with improved activity and ADMET properties.
Intellectual contributions from several lab members stimulated new combinations of nitrene precursors and silver catalysts for chemoselective aza-Bchner reactions to arenes to access versatile azepine scaffolds. Future work will elaborate these unusual building blocks to explore novel azepane chemical space that is underrepresented in current drug screening libraries.
The development and implementation of a high-throughput experimentation platform for the heterogenous silver-catalyzed NT reactions uncovered several unexpected and more environmentally friendly solvents to replace the usual chlorinated solvents used for NT. These discoveries will facilitate more ready adoption of our methods by industrial collaborators.



 In addition to broad impacts associated with streamlining industrially important reactions and minimizing environmental impact, this project has provided several post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students with numerous opportunities for technical training and professional development. For example, our collaboration with Prof. Peng Liu has enabled group members to travel to Pitt to learn ab initio computational methods. Students on the project have presented their work at conferences that include ACS meetings, the National Organic Symposium and several Gordon Research Conferences. Eleven Ph.D. students have received training under this NSF grant, five of whom are women and two of whom are underrepresented students in STEM. Graduate students have had opportunities to hone their experimental techniques, learn advanced spectroscopic techniques, meld experimental work with computation and data science, participate in outreach and educational activities, and take on leadership roles in conceptualizing and mentoring younger students in new project areas. These activities have been key to increasing their big-picture view of the project, exercising their creativity and developing their organizational/leadership skills, preparing them for leadership positions in academia, the chemical industry or government. In addition, three undergraduates have played key roles in this work and are listed as co-authors on publications funded by this grant. Students supported by this work have gone on to industry positions at GSK, BMS, PPD and other pharmaceutical companies, national labs (Los Alamos National Lab), academic positions at University of South Florida and Ohio University and Ph.D. programs at the University of Florida and Princeton.
